results.title: Insomnia
results.creator_credit: United States. Dept. of the Navy
results.brief_description: This US Navy Training Film looks at the problem of insomnia, and the personal distress which it can cause. Indicates that the problem is widespread, suggests ways of alleviating it, and stresses individual differences.

results.title: Inside the world of your dreams
results.brief_description: Dr Christopher Evans, through interviews with people, some of them well known, like children’s author Alan Garner and comedian Dave Allen, and his own comments sum up the existing knowledge about dreams, which are thought to be essential to mental health. Cast includes Alan Garner, Dave Allen, and Dr. Christopher Evans.

results.title: Inside the square [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Jaya Balendra and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: This is the story of two unknown London-based architects and their journey as winners in an international design competition in 1997, held by the then Premier of Victoria, Jeff Kennett, to create a bold new civic and cultural centre for Melbourne. Unlike the Sydney Opera House which was a single entity, Federation Square was more about a multitude of uses - restaurants, cinemas, bars, public spaces and a last minute addition, the National Gallery of Victoria. In 1998, Don Bates and Peter Davidson of Lab Architecture Studio teamed up with local based firm Bates Smart on a project of such magnitude, controversy and conflict that it took six years and more than 5000 people to complete. The program follows the final year of construction in the lead up to the opening of Federation Square and contains interviews with many of those involved including Don Bates, Peter Davidson, Dimity Reed (Architecture writer and critic), Peter Seamer (CEO, Federation Square Management), Tony Cosma (Project Manager, Multiplex), and Stan Liacos (Marketing Manager, Federation Square Management). The radical design of the buildings caused constant conflict and dispute between the architects and the builders, likewise with the builders and sub-contractors and the fact that the project was started before the architects had even finished their designs also created major problems from budget blow-outs, revisions in design to compromise and extended delays in completion. A documentary presenting the human side of one of Australia’s biggest public projects since the Opera House. Narrated by Justin Murphy.

results.title: Inside the reef: The Whitsundays
results.creator_credit: Len Beard and National Nine News
results.brief_description: This video, presented by Dean Felton, is the second in a two volume set that takes an authoritative look at all aspects of the Great Barrier Reef, from its formation and constant process of dynamic change to its natural and human habitation. This is a remarkable expedition through the magnificent Whitsunday Islands, highlighting the delicate environmental balance that must be struck between man and the reef’s fragile beauty. Experience the many worlds that exist within the extraordinary Whitsunday Islands group; the romance of isolated adventure; the mysterious spiritual history of the local islanders; roller-coaster rides on the trade winds across spectacular waters; the sheer indulgence of the most lavish and exotic resorts in the world; and meet the rugged individuals and fascinating characters who have made the reef wilderness their home. This sumptuously filmed documentary also looks at tourism on the reef and asks the question; is it responsible development or an environmental threat.

results.title: Inside the reef: from sand to coral
results.creator_credit: Len Beard and National Nine News
results.brief_description: This video, volume one in a two volume set looks at the Great Barrier Reef from top to bottom, above and below the water, its past and its future. The reef itself is actually a chain of thousands of coral reefs and billions of life forms, stretching more than 2,000 kilometres down the East Coast of Australia, from Cape York Peninsula in Far North Queensland to Fraser Island near the border of northern New South Wales. This is a definitive journey into the world’s largest living organism - the Great Barrier Reef. With stunning aerial photography and magical underwater sequences you explore the natural wonder of Fraser Island, and the fragile ecology of the largest sand island in the world through to the unparalleled beauty of the Coral Cays that straddle the reef. Marvel at a myriad of unique and bizarre under-water species and experience spectacular footage deep within the world’s most celebrated diving spots. The producers focus on the issue of the demands of people versus the need to preserve forever the overwhelming beauty of the Great Barrier Reef, in order that it be there for future generations to witness and enjoy!

results.title: Inside the kill box: fighting the Gulf War
results.creator_credit: Kurt Sayenga, Martha Adams and Discovery Channel
results.brief_description: Made for the Discovery Channel in America, “Inside the kill Box: Fighting the Gulf War” is an examination, strictly from an American and coalition perspective, of the strategies and weaponry that allowed a victory in Kuwait against Saddam Hussein. The Gulf war (1990-91) was considered to be the first war to be played live on television, and the graphics on display here, with tanks exploding and targets being decimated, makes one think of a video game. Features an array of interviews with various pilots, strategists, and soldiers, as well as with major players such as Dick Cheney, George Bush Snr, Norman Schwarzkopf and Colin Powell. Two interviews of particular interest are with two pilots who were tortured under captivity. Whilst the technical analysis of the war tools is interesting, there remains a pro-America sentiment that disallows any semblance of a balanced perspective.

results.title: Inside the Australian ballet
results.creator_credit: Bob Hardie, Matt Dow and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Inside the Australian ballet examines the people behind the Australian Ballet Company. Consisting of 68 dancers, performing over 180 shows a year, the company is one of the hardest working in the world. With interviews throughout of some of the company’s top dancers (past and present), this documentary illustrates the hardship and dedication demanded from all dancers involved. The documentary looks at some of the artistic achievements of the Company, the artistic process itself, psychological motivations, physical injury and psychological health and frames this in terms of career management and personal aspirations. Featured artists: Steven Heathcote, Miranda Coney, David McAllister, Justine Summers, Lisa Bolte, Matthew Trent, Nicole Rhodes, Geon Van Der Wyst, Lindy Wills, Daryl Brandwood, Shane Placentino, Sarah Peace, Jason Duff. With excerpts from the following productions: Bella Figura, Mirror Mirror, Coppelia, The Vertiginous Thrill of Exactitude. Narrated by Rod Young.

results.title: Inside the atom
results.creator_credit: Jack Olsen, Sydney Newman and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: The work of scientists at the Canadian Atomic Research Centre at Chalk River, Ontario. Includes a brief explanation of atomic theory, the splitting of the atom and chain reactions. Considers atomic energy as a potential source of a new industrial revolution and mentions the present use of radioactive isotopes for the treatment of cancer and also for agricultural research. Shows research work being done to develop atomic energy as a source of industrial power.

results.brief_description: Shows how a radio program is created and features, among others, a disk jockey and a young radio interviewer who discuss the style of writing and speaking suitable for a young audience.

results.title: Inside Newfoundland
results.creator_credit: Roger Morin, Sydney Newman and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Canada’s tenth province—its people, its resources, its way of life. The camera shows us St. John’s, the capital city; Cornerbrook, pulp and paper center; and Bell Island with its iron mine. The greatest wealth of Newfoundland is her people, and a visit with Fred Greeley, inshore fisherman and his family, introduces us to our fellow Canadians. Finally the importance of Newfoundland’s airports is stressed, and we visit Gander, where international air travellers come and go from the four corners of the globe.
